metadata.title: Nano-objects - sculpting and shape in molecular material design (The Pierre Gilles de Gennes ILCS prize lecture)

sections.text:
ARTICLE HISTORY Received 13 May 2019
KEYWORDS Hexatic; TGB; NTB; splay nematic; supermolecule

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
When gold is taken and reduced in size its starts off with a lustrous yellow colour, but as its size is reduced its colour changes to orange, then red, and to purple [1]. The colour change is effectively due to the properties of the surface becoming competitive with those of the bulk as we enter into the nanoscale regime. Similarly, in liquid crystal systems, the formation of micelles can be predicted from the competition between the bulk and surface packing of amphiphiles [2–7]. For molecular materials, the crossover in the dominance of the surface over the bulk appears to be at the cusp of the change over from the molecular to
the macromolecular scale [8]. In the nanoscale regime there is competition again but this time between steric shape and electrostatic interactions, whereas in the mesoscale range shape appears to dominate. Compare the following two materials 4-pentyl-4ʹ-cyanobiphenyl (5CB) [9] and 1,7-di-(1”-cyanobiphenyl-4-yl)heptane (CB7CB) [10]. Both materials exhibit a nematic phase, and in addition, CB7CB exhibits the unusual twist-bend phase. 4-Pentyl-4ʹ-cyanobiphenyl (5CB) is a well-known material due to its applications in displays, and as a consequence, it has many imitators such as PCH and CCH [11–16]. On the other hand, 1,7-di(1”-cyanobiphenyl-4-yl)heptane (CB7CB) is a relatively new compound, but because of its novel phase
CONTACT John W. Goodby john.goodby@york.ac.uk

behaviour, it too has many imitators. The remarkable difference between the two compounds is in their imitators, depending on adjustments to its chemical structure, 5CB’s imitators have wildly different properties, whereas the properties of CB7CB appear to be unaffected. In the nanoscale regimes, it appears that polarizability dominates over shape, whereas in the mesoscale range it is the reverse (Figure 1).
In this article we examine the following issues related to size and shape of molecular objects:
(i) The sensitivity of electrostatic behaviour over shape in terms of the three display materials 5CB, PCH, and CCH, and in the balance of inplane ordering of hexatic and crystal phases.
(ii) The effect of changing shapes of molecules, such that they affect the layer organization in rod-like materials, thereby raising the question over the nature of the layers in smectic phases, and what this means for nomenclature. Are smectic phases 1D Crystals or is this relevant to just lamellar phases?
(iii) Does the packing together of disc-like molecular objects form columnar phases with twodimensional crystalline organization, and what are the consequences for comiscibility? (iv) As we increase the size of molecular objects, and sculpt their shapes does this have the impact of creating molecular grains, which can have their own packing constraints? And lastly,
(v) What happens when we go beyond the range of the molecule?

sections.heading: 2. Electrostatics versus steric packing in nano-molecular materials
sections.text:
A perennial question asked of those that design and prepare liquid crystals is, ‘What are the most important aspects of chemical structure to use in design; steric shape or the incorporation of polar moieties?’ For years the approach taken has been one of evaluating the possibility of allowable polarizability, which means where are the ‘conjugative groups’, and will steric structure allow those groups to interact via polarizability with those in closely packed neighbouring molecules? For small molecules, this methodology led to the rational design of many of the liquid crystals used in liquid crystal displays, including the active electro-optic materials, the retardation films, and aligning agents. A now classical example of this approach is with the development of molecules possessing terminal nitriles for applications in nematogens of positive dielectric anisotropy. This began with the preparation of the 4-alkyl-4ʹ-cyano-biphenyls (as described above) and the realization that stable, colourless, room temperature nematogens suitable for display use was possible. George Gray dispelled the idea that this achievement was mere serendipity with his comment ‘I knew what I was doing by using the cyano group to compensate for loss of molecular length, while at the same time providing the strongly polar molecular structure needed for the electric field to switch on the display. This I stress was not luck . . . the fundamental science was secure . . . . . . we knew what we were doing’ [17]. The inventions of the cyanobiphenyls were quickly followed by the very important imitators 4-(trans-4-alkylcyclohexyl)benzonitriles (nPCHs), and trans-4-(trans-4-alkylcyclohexyl) cyclohexylcarbonitriles (CCHs), shown in Figure 2.
The comparison between the chemical structures and the temperature ranges plus clearing points of the nematic phases for these compounds often confounds many [18,19]. Why would materials that possess a lesser degree of polarizability possess more thermally stable nematic phases? Their chemical structures in terms of molecular length and breadth and polar groups are effectively the same, and yet the least polarizable material has the highest clearing point! The answer lies in the allowable locations of their dipolar and quadrupolar interactions, which affect the aspect ratios of interacting pairs of molecules, as shown in the figure. Thus at dimensions of approximately 3 nm, the electrostatic interactions are dominating over those of steric packing.
The nature of this work and its context in the industrial development of electrooptic devices still continues to this day; however, the level and extent of theFigure 1. Molecular shape starts to dominate as the molecular size is increased.
intermolecular interactions and the effects on mesophase formation are found mostly in the homes of academic research. For example, the effects of the sensitivities and strengths of the intermolecular interactions are demonstrated via the studies on the layered B phase. There are at least two forms of the B phase, the hexatic modification and the soft crystal form. The hexatic phase has its rod-like molecules oriented vertically to the layer planes and arranged in hexagonally close-packed arrays. The in-plane molecular ordering is quasi-long range extending over distances from 15 to 60 nm, where the orientation of the hexagonal array is long-range. This type of ordering is called bond orientational ordering after the theoretical work of Kosterlitz and Thouless [20] and Halperin and Nelson [21], that showed a two-dimensional system could melt via the formation of long-range orientational order. The out of plane order is short-range, and so the phase has a stacked hexatic structure. Conversely the crystal
B phase, although having the same packing arrangements as the hexatic phase, has long-range positional and bond orientational ordering. Sometimes the crystal B phase also has stacking transitions from ABAB to ABCABC perpendicular to the layers [22]. Therefore, the molecules will have almost identical interactions in both B forms, which have the same symmetries.
Compare the two materials hexyl 4ʹ-pentyloxybiphenyl-4-carboxylate (65OBC) and hexyl 4ʹ-pentyloxybiphenyl-4-thiocarboxylate (65OBTC) [23–25]. The only difference between the two materials is that 65OBC is an ester, and 65OBTC is a thioester. Both have the same donor pentyloxy groups and the same biphenyl core units, however, the thioester is a weaker acceptor, and therefore has less repulsive electrostatic interactions. The weaker interactions of the thioester allow the molecules of 65OBTC to pack more tightly than the molecules of 65OBC, thereby favouring the formation of crystal B phases.
Figure 2. Effect of the location of quadrupoles on nematic phase stability for the device materials 5CB, 5 PCH, and 5CCH.
Examples of the POM textures of 65OBC and the related material propyl 4ʹ-pentylbiphenyl-4-thiocarboxylate (35BTC) [25] are shown together in Figure 3. Photomicrograph (a) shows the focal-conic texture of the hexatic B phase of 65OBC with black crosses for the hyperbola and elliptical lines of optical discontinuity. Photomicrograph of (c) shows the texture of 35BTC where the domains are angular due to the extent of the out-of-plane correlations, which in turn also deform the structures of the focal-conic defects. Photograph (b) shows the transition between the smectic A phase and the B phase of 35BTC. The fan-like domains are crossed by lines, which are due to one phase growing in the other. After the transitions, the lines disappear and the texture heals. The changes observed demonstrate the presence of the crystal B phase of 35BTC, which was subsequently confirmed by X-ray diffraction.
These results indicate that the electrostatic interactions between the molecules effectively determine the subtleties of mesophase formation and stability of objects in the nanoscale size regime. However, it is worthwhile at this point also considering the steric interactions. Often steric shape is considered as being approximately static, but this is unlikely as the rod-like molecules are rotating rapidly about their long axes, often tumbling end-over end at a slower rate, and with numerous conformational inversions and rotations. Hence, simulations of liquid crystals usually consider molecules as being ellipsoidal. However, it is relatively simple to determine the shape of a molecular architecture via the calculation of the minimum moment of inertia of the minimum energy structure [26]. Rotation about the minimum moment of inertia gives the
rotational volume of the chemical structure. Packing together of the rotational volumes of the molecules in an antiparallel arrangement approximates to the organization in the layer planes. The intermolecular distance can hence be determined from the densest packing together of the molecules, as shown in Figure 4. However, X-ray diffraction shows that the intermolecular distance (3 to 5 Å) is too small in comparison to the calculated value (10 to 12 Å), and that the molecules must share space. Consequently, the local molecular motion must be within the same molecular envelopes and coordinated to some degree as shown in the figure. Therefore, the time scales for the molecular motions means that steric shape is relatively unimportant in the nanoscale regime, and the allowable weak electrostatic interactions, such as quadrupolar coupling shown in the figure, between the molecules as they rotate, oscillate, vibrate, flip, or insert from layer to layer determine mesophase formation and durability. Molecular clustering at this scale is therefore relatively meaningless, unless it precedes a phase transition.

sections.heading: 3. Size-exclusion and one-dimensional order
sections.text:
In the nanoscale regime, there are some instances where steric size and shape matters, and in the following two cases are described because they have direct comparisons with conventional low molar mass materials; these are size exclusion, and chirality distortion and fixation.
In size exclusion the molecular architecture is sculpted in such a way as to create a structure where rods, discs, or spheres are distorted by the incorporation of a substituent that that is comparative in size to the
original structure. For example, cyanobiphenyls, as shown in Figures 1 and 2, form interdigitated bilayer structures in smectic A phases due to antiparallel pairing of molecules formed through quadrupoler coupling of the donor-acceptor groups. For most examples of alkyl and alkoxy cyanobiphenyls, the layer spacing in the smectic A phase is 1.4x the molecular length, as determined by X-ray diffraction [27]. This form of the smectic A phase is classified as SmAd. Moreover the layer spacing is temperature invariant, exemplifying the stability of the structure, i.e. the layer spacing is determined by the location of the quarupole, and not by the steric shape. Figure 5 shows the layer spacing as a function of temperature for decyl and undecyl -oxy-4ʹ-cyano-biphenyl (10OCB, M30 and 11OCB, M33, respectively).
The incorporation of a substituent at the terminus of the alkyl chain can dramatically change the properties and structures of the mesophases formed. For instance, the incorporation of a tertiary butyl group (C(CH3)3) at the terminus increases the relative volume of 11OCB by 19% based on 11OCB, which has the effect of increasing the layer spacing from 1.4x to 1.55x of the molecular length (d/l), rising to approximately 1.63 for a reduced temperature of 25°C. Thus, unlike 11OCB that has a layer spacing that is invariant with respect to temperature, for the tert-butyl analogue
there is an increase in layer spacing of over 16% as the temperature falls.
Similar behaviour was also observed for other terminal groups as shown in Figure 5. Again the layer spacing was found to increase as the temperature was reduced. The change in the layer spacing was found to increase linearly in each case as a function of the reduced temperature, with the trend being approximately the same for all of the different terminal groups. Conversely, the relative volumes of the end groups, with respect to 110BC that are given in the figure, vary from 1.19 to 1.46. Thus, the trends appear to be unaffected by the size, shape, polarity, and volume of the terminal units, indicating that the chemical nature of the units appears irrelevant [28].
The overall behaviour of the materials studied indicates that as the mesophases condense on falling temperature the terminal substituents are being squeezed into the interfaces between the layers, as shown in Figure 6, thus better defining the layers. However, the relative sizes of the terminal groups with respect to the interfacial volume do not affect this process, and so the layer spacing varies similarly for all of the materials as a function of temperature. As a consequence, the layer structure becomes firmer as a function of temperature relative to the layers formed by 10OCB and 11OCB.
Consequently, the layered mesophases of the terminally substituted materials either cannot be defined classically as SmAd or that the SmAd phase is not a separately defined mesophase relative to the other smectic A phases (SmA1 and SmA2). Furthermore, better defined layer structuring has the potential for creating one-dimensional structures with long-range ordering, i.e. 1D crystals.
Similar effects with respect to layer structuring are expected to occur for mesophases that possess anticlinic structures as opposed to synclinic. These are generally found for ferroelectric and antiferroelectric examples of smectic C phases. Typically, the molecules of materials that exhibit these structures have twisted crankshaft shapes as shown by the (R) and (S) enantiomers of 1-methylheptyl 4ʹ-[[(4ʹ’-n-alkoxyphenyl)propioloyl]oxy]biphenyl-4-carb oxylates (14P1M7), depicted in Figure 7 [29,30].
For this particular material, the location of the stereogenic centre is adjacent to the aromatic core, which restricts rotational motion about the joint between the two. On condensation of the phases, as the temperature falls the layer structure changes from synclinic (ferroelectric) to anticlinic (antiferroelectric) via a ferrielectric state as the tilt angle saturates, see Figure 8. It is important
to note that the phase transitions between these phases are not reversible with respect to temperatures, unlike those for the clearing point and the smectic A to smectic C transitions. Supercooling indicates the presence of either a kinetically related transition or the formation of a frustrated or soft crystal phase.
In the synclinic phase with a density modulated layered structure there would be transmission across the layer interfaces communicating the tilt orientation of the molecules from one layer to the next. But because the molecules of 14P1M7 are chiral the twist in the molecular architecture causes a rotation of the layers. In the extreme case, the twisted packing of the molecules will rotate the layers in a full circle (Figure 9). This is highly unlikely, but instead, the rotation of the molecules through 180° from one layer to the next will compensate for the twist of the crankshaft structure, and the layers will form naturally with an anticlinic arrangement of the molecules.
However, there is one major difference that results from the formation of anticlinic order from synclinic, which is the layers are required to be better defined for the tilt left-tilt right arrangement in the anticlinic structure, otherwise the structure would not be stable [31].
Figure 6. The structural change in the layer interfaces upon cooling for the terminally substituted 4-methyleneoxy-4ʹ-cyanobiphenyls.
The anitclinic phase therefore has a more crystallinic nature perpendicular to the layers, yielding in effect a 1D crystalline structure, whereas for the synclinic phase there is no need for firm layering as the tilt is transmitted between the layers; thus the layers are softer.
Another outcome of these results is that the smectic CA is misclassified as a smectic C phase. There is a clearly defined transition between the synclinic and anticlinic phases, and so the phases should not share the same code letter C, and moreover, they do not share the same symmetries, C2h for the synclinic phases and D2h for the anticlinic phase. For the purposes of classification, consideration should made in giving the anticlinic phase a new code letter (it was at one time suggested that it should be called smectic O) [32]. However, given that phases with hard layer structures
are nearer to being 1D crystals may be they should be called ‘lamellar’ phases in order to be in line with notations being used in biological and polymeric systems. Similar issues also apply to the synclinic and anticlinic sub-phases of the B2 phase of bent-core materials. In some examples of these materials X-ray diffraction shows a number of out-of-plane reflections indicating that the layers are relatively firm.

sections.heading: 4. Two-dimensional order and defect stabilization
sections.text:
Having investigated the effect of sterics on the layer ordering in smectic-lamellar phases, and the potential for the formation of one-dimensional structuring, two-
Figure 8. The structures of the ferro-, ferri- and antiferroelectric mesophases. The synclinic ferrophase is more disordered at the layer interfaces than the anticlinic antiferrophase.
Figure 7. Chemical structure and transition temperatures for 1-methylheptyl 4ʹ-[[(4ʹ’-n-alkoxyphenyl)propioloyl]oxy]biphenyl-4-carboxylates (14P1M7).
dimensional systems are investigated in this section. Packing in two dimensions for rod-like molecules has been discussed in the first section in terms of quasi long-range ordering in hexatic phases, but the ordering of columns composed of disc-like nano-objects is possibly a more likely source for finding long-range twodimensional order.
In terms of the co-miscibility of two-component systems in binary phase diagrams, one-dimensional crystal phases are potentially more likely to mix than twodimensional systems. Experimental studies have been performed on materials that have disc-shaped molecules,
starting with nematic discogens, as shown in Figure 10 [33]. The two substituted triphenylenes, A and B, in the figure only exhibit nematic phases, and in the binary phase diagram, there is continuous miscibility over the whole concentration range. The curve for the melting points shows a minimum in the 30% mol wt region that could be hiding a eutectic point. Thus, the phase diagram appears classical and similar to phase diagrams observed for materials possessing rod-like molecules. If we examine a similar experiment, but this time between two materials that exhibit columnar mesophases where the columns are hexagonally close packed, in the centre of the
Figure 9. Synclinic layer formation (left) at the transition to the anticlinic phase. Anticlinic tilt directions on passing from one layer to the next (right) forms a more stable structure for the anticlinic phase.
diagram there is an apparent eutectic point for mixtures between the twomaterials, see Figure 11. However, in this case, the eutectic appears to be that between the columnar phases, and the transition to the solid-state (solid A + solid B) shows no eutectic point as the temperature varies only over a range of approximately 25°C. Similar behaviour has also been observed for other materials possessing disc-like molecules. Thus, it appears that columnar phases are either immiscible or that they behavemore like soft crystal phases than liquid crystals.
Furthermore, it is interesting to note that the chemical structures of the two materials in each of the phase diagrams are similar, as they are also between the phase diagrams. As the nematogenic materials are co-miscible it indicates that the immiscibility of the columnar phases
is unlikely to be due to chemical dissimilarities between the materials shown in Figure 11 [33].
Although the molecules in the above two studies have similar disc diameters, for a number of the other studies this is not particularly so. In which case the columnar phases of mixtures must have irregular crosssectional structures/diameters, and as a consequence, the packing of the columns into hexagonal arrays may be difficult, as shown in Figure 12. But between the columns, there are defects where the flexible liquid-like chains meet to fill the spaces between the columns. The defects therefore can also form hexagonal arrays, which are rotated by 30° relative to the molecular arrays. Hence, there are potentially two forms of 2D-lattices. Thus, the columnar structure and phase will be
Figure 11. Phase diagram for temperatures of phase transitions (°C) as function of concentration for binary mixtures (mol%) of compound B in mixtures with compound A.
stabilized by the defects in addition to the lateral packing of the molecular columns [34].
The evidence for soft-crystal behaviour for columnar phases can be seen via dendritic growth of the phase as it forms from the isotropic liquid, as shown by the texture in the right-hand of Figure 12. The formation of dendrites is common to physical and biological materials alike, but usually in both cases, they are associated with nucleation and crystallization processes. Coupled with the phase diagrams, dendritic growth indicates the hexagonal columnar phase is two-dimensionally ordered, which implies there may be a need for a new understanding of phase diagrams in low dimensional systems.

sections.heading: 5. Three-dimensional soft crystals and phase transitions
sections.text:
There are numerous crystallinic cubic bicontinuous mesophases in liquid crystal systems, ranging from Blue phases of chiral compounds to the gyroid phases of di-block copolymers. All of the structures have no periodic ordering of the molecules and the cubic structure is derived from the 3D-organization of defects. At the nano-length scale, and without molecular chirality as in Blue Phases, the 4ʹ-alkoxy-3ʹ-nitrobiphenyl-4-carboxylic acids and the 4ʹ-alkoxy-3ʹ-cyanobiphenyl4-carboxylic acids exhibit D phases [35], which also have bicontinuous cubic structures for the C16 and C18 alkoxy derivatives [36]. The D phase appears between the transitions from the smectic A or liquid to the smectic C phase. A photomicrograph of this transition for 4ʹ-hexadecyloxy-3ʹ-nitrobiphenyl-4-carboxylic acid is shown in Figure 13, where the D phase appears optically isotropic as expected for a cubic structure. As with the anticlinic-synclinic transitions described previously, the phase transitions with respect to the D phases are not reversible either, and may be subject to supercooling. Moreover, depending
on the heating and cooling rates there is also the possibility that a columnar phase will appear, again associated with poor reversibility of the phase transitions, as shown in Figure 13.
The D phase only appears at long aliphatic chain lengths for these acids, which also have a propensity to H-bond to give rod-like entities that are twice the molecule length. This will have two effects, (i) increase of the dynamic fluctuations in the associations between the molecules, and (ii) in the formation of a bilayer organization where the H-bonding is separated from the packing of the aliphatic chains. Terminal or lateral H-bonding within the layer structures of the smectic A and C phases is potentially the most likely outcome, and the phases will have 1Dorganized layers, which are disrupted by the interactions of the strong dipoles of the lateral nitro or cyano groups. Whichever process occurs at the phase transition from A to C, there clearly is a change from a layered organization through 2- and 3-ordered phases, where there is not a sequence for these phase changes to occur, i.e. 1D to 2D to 3D; it could occur with any sequence and with any number of the phases, e.g. 1D and 2D, or 2D and 3D. This is completely different when compared to nanostructured liquid crystals where there is a known sequence or pattern of phase transitions and phase types, i.e. N, SmA, SmC, HexB . . . etc.
However, this important aspect of this old material is that the supercooling of the phase transitions the D phase is crystallinic as opposed to liquid crystalline, and that the crystal structure is based on a lattice of defects and not positional ordering of the molecules.

sections.heading: 6. Towards mesoscale materials: complexity and molecular grains
sections.text:
Beyond the molecule, larger material systems including polymers and dendrimers have been investigated, along
with supermolecular materials. In terms of liquid crystals, the difference between these classifications of large molecular architectures lies in whether or not they behave as internally nano-segregated systems or do they behave more like structurally unified architectures. For example, the first set of materials includes dendrimers and polymers, and related materials where there are mesogenic units bound to, and decoupled from, a none-mesogenic scaffold. In this way, the self-organization process is essentially determined by the mesogenic units, which carry the scaffold with them. In the second set, the supermolecular materials are themselves mesogenic, for example, in di-block copolymers, or if they possess mesogenic units they are not decoupled from a non-mesogenic scaffold.
For the first set of giant molecular materials, they usually do not have discrete molecular architectures, but instead are composed of mixtures of oligomeric and polymeric species, whereby saturation of the degree of polymerization can affect physical properties that are reproducible [37]. However, for decoupled mesogenic units, the relative density of the mesogenic units can render the dispersity as being irrelevant. This is demon-
strated for the nano-object shown in Figure 14. This material has a central pentaerythritol scaffold, which has four arms that can be derivatized and in order to attach a relatively large number of mesogens into the overall structure dendrons have been attached, where each dendron has three mesogenic units. For full substitution, there are four dendrons and carrying 12 mesogenic units, whereas for threefold substitution there are three dendrons and 9 mesogenic units. Thus, there is therefore a substantive difference in the two structures, but remarkably the melting points and clearing points of the two materials are almost identical. Thus, it appears that it does not matter to the giant molecular system whether three-arms are present or four-arms, the system simply does not know the difference. Laterally appended mesogens to the dendrons favour the formation of chiral nematic phases, and physical properties, such as helical pitch length, of the dendrimers, dendrons and mesogenic units are similar, indicating the dominance of the mesogenic units.
One of the more interesting features about the three-armed system is that the un-reacted fourth site has an acid moiety associated with it. Thus, this
location can act as a binding site, and potentially a catalytic site, and the system has the potential to act somewhat like a protein, with a binding site in its structure.
Attachment of the mesogenic units through their terminal locations tends to support the formation of liquid crystals that possess layered structures. This usually implies that the giant molecular architectures have become distorted in such a way as to become cylindrical in shape. In doing so, where the central scaffold is chemically different to the outer mesogenic units, there will a tendency to form a sub-layer of central units as shown in Figure 15 for a supermolecule that possesses a symmetrically substituted non-mesogenic fullerene scaffold. This material also possesses external mesogenic units based on cyanobiphenyls, but unlike the packing of the units in an interdigitated bilayer, as shown in Figure 1, for individual molecules the overlap for the supermolecule is mostly between the nitrile units, simply because interpenetration in the presence of the fullerene scaffold is difficult due to dense packing. This structure therefore has a layer structure that is identified with lamellar phases of polymeric systems, plus associated sub-layers, as shown in the figure.
Molecular distortion in such materials occurs due to the free space around the arms when they are spread out, but to minimize the free volume the arms pull inwards thereby increasing the density [38]. This will also decrease the conformational freedom and reduce
the complexity in the structure, thereby producing a molecular sheaf. The layered structure, however, will have its mesogenic units separated into one sublayer, the methylene chains into another, and a third comprising the scaffold units. Therefore, the out-ofplane ordering of the layers is long-range.
Figure 16 shows a similar giant molecule with a central octasilsesquioxane scaffold, bifurcation to give 2mesogenic units per dendron, thereby producing 16 mesogenic units attached by long flexible methylene chains to the siloxanebased scaffold [37,39]. The material possesses a layered structure, with a clearing point of 92°C from the lamellar A phase to the isotropic liquid. The molecular architecture is deformed as before, forming a cylindrical shape, with sub-layers being incorporated into the overall layered structure as shown in the figure. The giant molecules in Figures 15 and 16 have similar clearing points and phase behaviours, indicating for these types ofmaterial themesogen density and the nature of the scaffold do not markedly affect the phase properties, which are dominated by the packing of the mesogenic groups.
The second set of giant molecular materials requires the creation of unique/discrete covalently bound molecular architectures. A simple example of a liquid-crystalline supermolecular material is that of a ‘Janus grain’. This type of nano-object was theorized by de Gennes in his Nobel Lecture [40,41] in which he says, ‘Let me quote still another new animal: the Janus
grains, first made by Casagrande and Veyssie. The god Janus had two faces. The grains have two sides: one apolar and the other polar. Thus, they have certain features in common with surfactants.’ Figure 17 shows two examples of Janus Liquid Crystals that are composed of two faces one polar that possesses terminally attached cyanobiphenyl mesogenic units, and the other face is chiral and attached laterally to a central
point in the molecular scaffold. The polar face favours smectic properties and the other nematic. The difference between the two materials is that the orientation of the central scaffold is opposed to one another. Both materials exhibit chiral nematic phases demonstrating the dominance of the laterally appended mesogens, however, even though the hemispheres are the same for both materials, the transition temperatures are
Figure 17. Janus nano-objects that have two hemispheres, with one hemisphere composed of terminal polar groups, and the other laterally appended chiral groups. The difference between the two is the orientation of the central unit.
Figure 16. A giant molecular material based on an octasilsesquioxane central scaffold, and bifurcated dendrons to give 16 mesogens per chemical architecture.
affected by the orientation of the scaffold that is buried within the structure. Similarly, the lower material in the figure exhibits a ferroelectric smectic C phase. Thus, the two materials are acting differently due to the scaffold, which appears to be instrumental in mesophase stability and formation, and the materials are in effect nano-objects.
The nano-objects above were created by attaching dissimilar units to a scaffold, however, it is also possible to attach mesogenic units to a scaffold where they do not have a great deal of freedom of movement, i.e. via a short methylene chain. For this architecture, the properties will be dependent to a greater extent on the overall shape and surface coating of the nano-object. For example, a nanoobject is shown in Figure 18. In this architecture, 12 rodlike chiral mesogenic units are attached symmetrically by bifurcation to a fullerene C60 scaffold [42,43]. The linkages from themesogenic units to the scaffold are methylene chains of five pentamethylene units, which are of a relatively short length such that the mesogenic units are not decoupled from the scaffold. Lateral appendage now requires that the mesogenic rods are parallel to the spherical surfaces of the scaffolds, and because they are chiral they spiral on the surface, producing packing defects as shown in the lower part of the figure, and thereby naming the nano-object a molecular boojum. The surface substitution of the nano-object means that it can pack with similar objects to give condensed systems larger than those that can be achieved with molecular materials,
and at ambient temperature ranges. In the case of the material shown it is a glass up to 47°C, at which point it converts to a chiral nematic phase up to 103°C, whereupon it transforms into the liquid. Because the material has a discrete chemical structure it is pure and thermally stable, it also has phase transitions that are sharp, reversible, and reproducible. The pitch length of the chiral nematic phase is relatively stable as a function of temperature and is of use as an optical notch filter.
The possibilities for creating nano-objects are very great and the area is still relatively untouched. Most of the materials so far produced have central scaffolds that are rotationally symmetrical and decorated with rodlike mesogenic units. There are seemingly few supermolecular materials hierarchically decorated with bentcore, discotic, or phasmidic surface moieties, or with functional groups other than chiral moieties.
The design concepts for liquid-crystalline giant molecular materials and nano-objects can also be utilized in the creation of colloidal metal and semiconductor scaffolds that are decorated with mesogenic materials. Such materials result in the formation of metallic [44] or semi-conductor nanoparticles that can also be captured into self-organizing media.
This approach was used to coat particles based on quantum dots with the result that rational particle design was deployed to prevent aggregation of colloidal particles in liquid crystal media. In practice, a truly stable colloidal system was achieved using specially
coated Quantum Dots (QDs) of CdSe/ZnS dispersed in the nematic host 5CB [45]. The luminescent nature of QDs provided an opportunity to visualize the degree to which aggregation of NPs occurred in the LC matrix, with some coated particle systems being stable over a few years without coagulation.
The design procedure involved coating the QDs with a variety of phosphate ligands (1 to 4, plus TOPO) as shown in Figure 19. Evolution in their
design was to maximise the near surface coating of the QDs, such that the particle surface was not exposed. Typically, coatings have involved the use of one ligand to coat the whole surface, but for scaffolds that have a high degree of curvature, this may not be possible because the density of the ligands on the particle is not great enough to fill the space as the ligands splay at the surface. After a number of studies, it was found that the most stable colloidal system was one where mesogenic dendrons, as shown by structure 2 in the figure, were mixed with surfactants such as structures 3 and 4. This gave a combined coating that appeared almost as a molecular grass and trees filling the surface of the coating. In an oriented liquid crystal matrix, the molecules of the nematic phase penetrated the space around the particle with the dendron surfactants funnelling them in towards the surface where they become oriented by the shorter single-chain surfactants, as shown in Figure 20. In this arrangement, the coated particles were unable to come together to aggregate, and so the colloidal QDs were stable over long periods of time.
7. Elastic deformations and filling free space
So far most of the nano-objects described above have been relatively symmetrical in shape, however, atypicalshaped systems can introduce novel phase behaviour based on their abilities to densely pack in order to minimise the free volume. As a result, the molecules do not have periodic ordering, but their packing arrays in threedimensional space do. Consequently, the electrostatic
Figure 19. Variety of ligands that were attached to CdSe/ZnS quantum dots (QDs) to fully coat their surfaces.
interactions are not that important, and the shapes of the nano-objects determine mesophase formation.
For example, bi- and di-mesogens and bent-core materials through to polymesogens, as shown in Figure 21 exhibit the novel twist-bend mesophases [46–51]. Property-structure correlations show that the relationship between the clearing point and the temperature for the nematic to twist-bend phase transition is linear irrespective of the chemical structure of the mesogenic groups as listed in the figure. This result implies that the formation of the
twist-bend phase depends on molecular shape alone [52].
For the twist-bend phase, the bi- and di-mesogens have two mesogenic groups attached to one another by a flexible chain (usually methylene) of odd atom length (odd parity), such that the angle between the two mesogenic groups is approximately 120°. Thus the molecules have a flexible bend structure, and when they pack together in order to minimize the free volume they do so by forming a helical macrostructure as shown in Figure 22. Because the molecules are distributed randomly along the heliaxis, X-ray diffraction gives results similar to those obtained for the nematic phase, and hence the phase was called the nematic twist-bend phase. However, upon various syntheses of examples of materials that exhibit the twist-bend phase, and examinations of their structures and physical properties it became debatable that the twist-bend phase is nematic. Firstly, it does not have the same symmetry as the nematic phase, and secondly, the defect textures that it forms are not commensurate with those of the nematic phase. For example, three defect textures are shown in Figure 23, image (a) shows the fibre texture of the twist-bend phase produced via transmitted polarized light microscopy with the specimen sandwiched in a cell with unidirectional alignment and 5 μm spacing. Left- and right-hand helical domains are seen with differences between the contrasts due to the position of the polarizers. The other two textures (b and c) appear to be the same, and for the twist-bend phase, texture (b) they are called blocky. Texture (c) is not that of a twist-bend phase but a truncated focal-conic texture of the crystal B phase of N-(4-butyloxybenzylidene-4ʹ-heptylaniline (4O.7).
Figure 21. Template for the formation of dimesogens with different mesogenic moieties, or bimesogens possessing the same two units.
This Schiff base 4O.7 has been studied extensively by X-ray diffraction and shown to exhibit a crystal B phase that has long-range positional order in three dimensions [22]. Similarly, the twist-bend phase also exhibits longrange order [53], which is related to a helical structure where the pitch length is the equivalent to the layer spacing in the crystal B phase. The truncated nature of the focal-conic domains corresponds to the heliaxes being parallel to where the hyperbola would have been in a focal-conic domain. If the structure of the twist-bend phase was equivalent to that of the crystal B phase then there would be long-range order perpendicular to the ‘socalled layers’, as shown in Figure 24. In this picture, because of the long-range order, the curvatures of the hyperbola and ellipses of the confocal optical discontinuities are suppressed in favour of the formation of blocks within the ex-focal-conic domains. The block sizes are in effect the correlation lengths of the helical structures. Thus, the periodicity is due to helicity and not molecular position as it is with the crystal B phase; however, the
structures of the twist-bend and crystal B defects are the same. This point is important as microscopy only gives images of defects and local structures and not necessarily the positions of the molecules, but in this case, it also indicates the strength of the helical structure because the curvature of the heliaxis, associated with ellipse and hyperbola, is suppressed.
The pitch length for many twist-bend phases is of the order of two to three times the molecular length, and therefore the molecules can have any position along the axis of the helix, with around 4 to 5 molecules required to complete one full twist. Hence, the structure appears by X-ray diffraction to have no positional ordering of the molecules; therefore, the generation of the helical structure is due to dense packing of the molecules minimising the free volume of the system. If the molecules were to create layers in the formation of the helical structure then the phase would be similar in structure to the clock model of a ferrielectric phase [54,55], and without the presence of a helical
Figure 23. The helical texture (a) and the truncated focal-conic texture (b) of the twist-bend phase, and the truncated focal-conic texture of the crystal B phase (c).
Figure 24. The truncated focal-conic texture and the proposed structure of a truncated focal-conic domain of the twist-bend phase.
structure, layering would produce an anticlinic mesophase [56]. Subsequent cooling of a twist-bend phase into a smectic phase therefore would probably result in formation one of the various anticlinic variants of smectics C, I, and F. Recently, variants of smectic phases formed by bimesogens have been theorized and demonstrated [57,58].
There is also another orientation for viewing the twistbend phase and that is by observing the phase along the heliaxes. The helices can pack together into rectangular or hexagonal arrays, and thus the twist-bend phase can appear as a columnar phase. Such organizations are sometimes observed for biologically related materials such as poly(γbenzyl L-glutamate (PBLG) [59]. The helices also have the possibility of acting like screw dislocations in a normal phase. Located periodically they would act as vortices in a lattice, similar to the structure to the Abrikosov lattice found for the twist-grain boundary phase.
In general, nano-objects are therefore effectively molecular grains that are pushed tightly together, whose structure is determined by the elastic deformations of splay, twist and bend, where the minimum free volume is achieved through the twisting and bending of the molecular packing. This unusual state therefore has many characteristics of other phases in terms of structures, properties, and defects, but it is also unique in being created via elastic curvature. It is not a traditional nematic phase, and is certainly not a smectic or columnar phase, and its novelty requires further exploration beyond the confines of traditional molecular structure.
Extensive experimental studies on the process of taking materials from the nano-scale through the mesoscale regime increasingly demonstrate that shape grows in importance to the point where it dominates
the formation of mesophases, such as the twist-bend phase. Modelling and simulations are increasingly focusing on the shapes of particles in processes of self-assembly. In particular, there is interest in how shape entropy affects structure. Early results demonstrate that shape affects bulk structure due to the crowding of particles optimizing the local packing arrangements. Quoting van Anders et al. [60] they state, “Many natural systems are structured by the ordering of repeated, distinct shapes. Understanding how this happens is difficult because shape affects structure in two ways.
(i) How the shape of a cell or nanoparticle, for example, affects its surface, chemical, or other intrinsic properties.
(ii) The emergent, entropic effect that arises from the geometry of the shape itself, which we term shape entropy, and is not well understood”.
Having examined the packing properties of bent shaped dimesogens, the next step in this process was to examine oligomeric and polymeric systems [51]. Needless to say, they exhibited twist-bend phases as well. Another possibility was to change the structure such that two bentshaped molecules are attached to one another by a bridging group in the centre thereby creating a duplex molecule [61], as shown in Figure 25(a and b); the object being to see if two interwoven helices are formed as shown in figures (d) and (e), and indeed this is so. Molecular simulations of the duplex molecule showed that the two bent halves of the overall molecule are joined to one another in such a way as to give opposing bend directions, which form a double helix as shown schema-
tically in the figure. Packing more molecules into the double helix results in the formation of a co-axial cable or fibre.
The duplex material was found to melt at 123.7°C into the nematic phase, which transformed into the liquid at 172.9°C. Upon cooling a monotropic twistbend was formed at 117.2°C. The microscopic textures of the duplex nano-object are very similar to those of the di- or bi-mesogens described earlier. The blocky or truncated focal-conic texture is shown in Figure 26(a) and the helical fibre, or rope-like texture in (b). X-ray diffraction patterns (c and d) show the magnetically aligned nematic phase in picture (c) and the twist-bend phase in picture (d), where the phase transition into the twist-bend phase occurs with the loss of alignment. Thus, the results are consistent with the material exhibiting a twist-bend phase, but this time with a different double twist structure, which indicates that this is a new form of the twist-bend class of mesophases, and possibly the first example of polymorphism in such systems.
With the twist-bend and the twist-grain boundary modulated phases dependent on a helical structuring, we now turn to a new liquid crystal phase based on a splay modulation of the director in a nematic phase [62]. This new phase was first thought to be biaxial and found, by optical microscopic studies of schlieren textures, to have a lower symmetry than the uniaxial nematic phase.
The phase transition between the two forms of nematic phase was found to be weakly first order accompanied with splay fluctuations. When approaching the phase transition, the splay nematic constant is unusually low and approaches zero at the phase change. In analogy with the transition from the uniaxial nematic to the twistbend nematic phase, the transition is driven by instability towards splay orientational deformation, resulting in a periodically splayed structure, as shown in Figure 27, which is similar to the expulsion of twist in the twist-grain boundary phase. Consequently, the modulated splay phase is therefore biaxial and antiferroelectric.
Figure 26. The truncated focal-conic texture (a) and the helical fibre, or rope-like texture in (b) of the duplex bimesogen. The X-ray diffraction pattern of the magnetically aligned nematic phase (c), and the twist-bend phase (d). Alignment is lost at the transition into the twist-bend phase.
The splay nematic phase was first found in the liquid crystal family of 4-nitrophenyl 4-(3ʹ-alkoxy-4ʹ-alkoxybenzoyloxy)benzoates, as shown in Figure 28 for 4-nitrophenyl 4-(3ʹ-methoxy-4ʹ-methoxybenzoyloxy) benzoate [63]. The materials are related to the 4-alkoxyphenyl 4-(4ʹ-nitrobenzoyloxy)benzoates (DBnNO2 compounds), which exhibit incommensurate and reentrant behaviour of the nematic phase. The number of examples of splay nematic behaviour is somewhat limited and seems to be favoured by materials that have a low aliphatic chain content, meaning that the molecular architecture is relatively rigid. Another interesting point to note about the molecular structure is that there is a strong interaction between pairs of molecules through the overlapping of the nitro groups, as shown in the crystal structure in the figure. This pairing is similar to that of 5CCH shown in Figure 2.
The nematic and splay phases, and phase transition between the two, can be quite clearly seen by POM in Figure 29. In the splay phase defect structures that are not present in the uniaxial nematic phase can be observed, with the presence of two additional defect lines around the ±1 defects and one around the ±1/2 defects, which confirm the lower symmetry of the splay phase in comparison to the uniaxial nematic phase.
The two-dimensional scattering patterns obtained for the nematic phase at 140°C and for the splay phase 129°C are very similar, and shown together in Figure 30 (a and b, respectively). The SAXS and WAXS data were obtained across the entire temperature range for the phases giving results that suggest a continuous change in the degree of pairing of the molecules rather than a sudden change at the phase transition.
If we compare the twist-bend, twist-grain boundary and splay states we have the following:
(i) For the splay state, there is a phase transition to the nematic phase, and by definition, the two phases should not share the same liquid crystal classification. Moreover, there is a periodic modulation of the splay which is long-range, resulting in a state that has a different symmetry to that of the uniaxial nematic phase. There is, however, no periodic ordering of the molecules.
(ii) For the twist-bend state it too has a transition to the nematic phase, and again by definition should not share the same classification as N. There is also long-range periodicity associated with the twist modulation. To achieve this there is a combination of bend and twist. There is, however, no periodic ordering of the molecules.
Figure 29. The schlieren textures of the nematic and splay textures of 4-nitrophenyl 4-(3ʹ-methoxy-4ʹ-methoxybenzoyloxy)benzoate, plus the texture of the transition between the two phases.
(iii) For the twist-grain boundary phase [29,64–66], it was originally called a smectic A* phase based in the fact that it was helical, subsequently, it became known as the twisted smectic A or TGBA phase. But is it really a smectic A phase? After all, the layers are punctuated with vortices where the twist is expelled, and as the cores of the dislocations are approached there is a change from being A-like to C-like to orthoconical to nematic. In essence, it is a phase of mixed structures, where the elastic properties dominate the structure, and the picture of flat layers in-between rows of dislocations is not quite true as the layers distort upon entering into the defects, as shown in right-hand part of Figure 31.
Thus, we reach a point whereby the splay and twistbend states have been called nematic phases, but because of the transitions from these states to the uniaxial nematic phase, the conclusion must be that the nematic phase, like the smectic state, exhibits polymorphism, which is at odds with the original definition of the nematic phase given by de Gennes. An alternative for classifying these phases is to introduce a new form of nomenclature.

sections.heading: 8. Summary
sections.text:
Apart from the development of complexity in molecular architecture and the accompanying discovery of numerous phases, shape has become entwined with the nomenclature systems used in liquid crystals.
Originally our naming system introduced by Friedel in 1924 was straightforward; we had code letters of N, Sm and Ch, to define the phases he called nematic, smectic or cholesteric. Nematic and smectic phases were given their names from observations of the bulk phases, and although the nematic phase remained as a single phase, smectics were later found to be polymorphic. Conversely, the cholesteric phase was named after the derivatives of cholesterol investigated by Reinitzer and Lehmann. Unfortunately, identifying a mesophase by a chemical architecture sowed the seeds that would generate future problems in the consistency of classification of liquid crystals, such that now we have mesophases named after chemical structure and shape. This approach has generated names such as discotics, sanidics, calamitics, chromonics, bananas and bent-core. The implication is that the structures of some phases are based on a certain molecular shape, rather than a particular mesophase being exhibited by materials possessing a variety of molecular shapes. For example, other than discs; rod, sanidic, chromonic, amphiphilic and phasmidic types of material can also form columnar phases.
Alternatively, it has been suggested that symmetry could be used to classify mesophases, but there is a major problem here with duplication, because many phases possess the same symmetries, and alternatively, they can have the same nomenclature code letter but with different symmetries. For example, this duplicity has entered into the classification of the nematic phase, which appears now to have become polymorphic. Also physical properties, such as chiral, ferroelectric,
antiferroelectric, polar, and apolar have been used to classify mesophases, resulting in a string of possible code letters to identify a phase.
It can be seen from the descriptions of some of the phases in the article that certain nomenclature letters may no longer be appropriate, for example, the smectic Ad phase now seems to have a variable layer spacing related to the bilayer structure, unlike the 1.4x the molecular length of that originally defined cyanobiphenyls.
May be an alternative is to use structural definitions introduced by Leadbetter [67] and to extend his ideas fully to three dimensions. He defined three levels of positional ordering; long-range, quasi long-range, and short-range.
(i) For long-range positional order, the X-ray diffraction pattern exhibits sharp peaks due to the long-range order, but due to thermal motion, the amplitude of the peaks decreases as the order of the peak increases.
(ii) For quasi-long-range order, which is found for hexatic phases, the positional order decays algebraically, and is proportional to r−η, where r is the distance from a reference point and η is a temperature-dependent constant. The diffraction pattern then contains broadened, cusp-like peaks instead of very narrow ones. The hexatic phase also has long-range orientational ordering of the packing array of the molecules.
(iii) For short-range order found in typical smectic and nematic phases, the positional order decays exponentially, meaning it is proportional to e−r/ξ, where ξ is a temperature-dependent constant, then the diffraction pattern contains even broader peaks.
In three dimensions, we could have combinations of all three possibilities, e.g. one long-range coordinate, one with geometric decay, and one with short-range order. For long-range order, these combinations could be associated with 1D, 2D, and 3D ordered crystals.
For the hexatic B phase, it has 2D quasi long-range ordering of the molecules within the layers, but perpendicular to the layers it is said to be stacked, however the extent of the out of plane correlation is not reported. The crystal B phase conversely has 3D long-range ordering. However, there is a problem of categorizing the order perpendicular to the layers because of the poor sensitivity of experimental techniques. Leadbetter defined the out-of-plane ordering by a sinusoidal density modulation. For smectic A and smectic C phases the layers are diffuse, and defining the layers becomes difficult, particularly in the presence of cybotactic groups, so this may be described as short-range out-of-plane ordering. Conversely, for materials possessing large molecular
entities or strongly dichotomous structures diffuse organization of layered structure becomes more difficult, and segregation occurs producing sub-layers. Such systems have long-range order and for polymeric and biological materials they are called lamellar phases. Where the layer planes are well defined such as at inversions of the tilt these would have longer range ordering.
Passing through this article we reach the twist-bend, splay, and twist-grain boundary phases along with the bicontinuous cubic phases. These phases are beyond the conventional. They are crystallinic in one form or another, having structures based on long-range positional ordering of defects or elastic distortions caused by crowded packing of molecular grains that minimise the free volume. However, the molecules themselves have no periodic ordering. There will be potentially more phases of this type where there is periodicity in space but the particles that support the structure have no particular organization.

Dedication
This paper is based on the lecture given at the 2018 International Liquid Crystal Conference in Kyoto, Japan. I dedicated the lecture to my friend and work colleague Pat Cladis who had recently passed away. Apart from her outstanding contributions to the science of liquid crystals, as described in her obituary by Brand and Pieranski, Pat greatly influenced our community through her support of many of our young researchers. When I was President of ILCS Pat was my Chair of the ILCS Awards Committee. Pat’s lead and continued support of the Glenn Brown Prize Program proved to be important to our graduating researchers, and the care she gave to them throughout the Awards ceremonies, and beyond into their careers greatly benefitted the general health of our Liquid Crystal family.
Then recently, I learned of the passing of Alan Leadbetter. Alan, like Pat, I had known for over 40 years. Alan was the first scientist working on liquid crystals that I came to know outside of Hull University. He was my PhD examiner and along with George Gray my first post-doctoral supervisor. As described in this paper, through Alan we came to realise that there were two smectic B phases. I often used to write to him about what is now known as the crystal B phase, calling it a modulated B phase, and it was through this work I ended up at Bell Laboratories working on hexatics. Alan was a totally unfazed person to work with; he took things like me losing half of the deuterated pivalonitrile I was making for him in his stride. In those days it cost more than my salary. Because of Alan’s modesty, over the years I came to realise just how important his studies were on the fundamentals of structure in liquid crystals. Indeed he was truly a great scientist. Looking back, I was incredibly fortunate to work with, and for both of, these remarkable people, who sadly are no longer part of the fabric of my life and that of liquid crystals in her obituary.

metadata.abstractText: Early liquid crystal compounds often had relatively simple molecular structures, but with the invention of electro-optical devices, the design of materials became increasingly important. Property-structure correlations have promoted computer-aided rational design to the point where it is becoming a necessity in the selection of compounds for preparation. For simple molecular architectures, allowable electrostatic interactions in the face of steric repulsion were used in a phenomenological way to generate new mesophases, such as the hexatic phase, and to engineer materials with desirable physical properties. Materials chemists, in the creation of substances of greater complexity, have built upon these forms of research. Interestingly, the larger the system often the more simply it becomes as the molecular bulk and shape begin to dominate over the surface interactions. Nano-objects of unique shapes, such as ‘Janus’ grains, created in the process of design can kindle the formation of new mesophases, such as the twistbend and splay phases generated through the crowding of molecular particles, and minimisation of the free volume. This article explores the development of the shapes of molecular grains and the mesophases they spawn. ARTICLE HISTORY Received 13 May 2019
